Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Coasts and Communities - Natural and Human Systems in Urbanizing Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award prepares Ph.D. students at the University of Massachusetts Boston with the skills to understand the interactions between natural and human systems and to develop appropriate policy solutions for urban and urbanizing environments. By emphasizing interdisciplinary collaboration and communication, this program aims to enable trainees to apply their innovative and sustainable solutions across geographical, political, and economic contexts.

Intellectual Merit: This program aims to increase understanding of the ways in which human activities impact coastal systems as well as the ways in which changes in coastal ecosystems affect human systems. Trainees will conduct research both in the Boston Harbor watersheds and in the Horn of Africa, in order to assess and address the environmental risks that emerge when natural and human systems interact. The program will engage four Ph.D. programs at the University of Massachusetts Boston ? environmental science, environmental biology, global governance and human security, and organizations and social change ? in the study of these two world regions.

Broader Impacts: This traineeship will promote environmental stewardship and innovation on a global scale by supporting comparative research in the Horn of Africa and in Boston. Trainees will learn from a diverse range of disciplines and perspectives as they become effective problem solvers of complex global environmental issues. Additionally, as a minority-serving institution, the University of Massachusetts Boston will attract underrepresented students to this program.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to establish new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries, and to engage students in understanding the processes by which research is translated to innovations for societal benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Coasts and Communities IGERT program at the University of Massachusetts Boston has had a profound impact on the faculty, graduate students, culture, curriculum, and indeed the approach in the School for the Environment and amonst the College of Science and Mathematics, College of Management, and the McCormack Graduate School of Policy and Global Studies.  The Coasts and Communities program has proven to provide transdisciplinary, transnational, and transformational experiences for all students and faculty involved. It has fundamentally enhanced the interactions of students and faculty among the four participating colleges as well as across the University with a realization and celebration that a transdisciplinary approach is necessary and effective to address complex, wicked, environmental problems. 

We have been able 1) to develop a new, two-semester, team-taught, transdisciplinary Coasts and Communities core course, 2) to develop an Environmental Innovation Clinic where teams of interdisciplinary graduate students work for real-world clients, 3) to establish the Boston Harbor Boot Camp as a cohort-building, immersive first experience for all graduate students, and 4) to shift the culture of our graduate faculty towards greater collaboration and community-based research. Throughout the program, our multi-disciplinary faculty and evolving cross-disciplinary graduate curriculum have allowed us to successfully train graduate students to think, act, and communicate across the science, policy, and management disciplines. We can now better engage a wide variety of stakeholders and incorporate their perspectives and priorities into resiliency planning, policy-making, and the implementation of sustainable solutions to issues facing urban coastal communities. These developments have led to over $10 million in new research funding for transdisciplinary research and educational activities.

Experiences in local New England environments as well as in Ethiopia and Rwanda have opened the minds of faculty and students to reassess the role of science in society, and to support graduate students in their quest to use their science to ?make a difference? in the world.  This new understanding, based on our experiences in the IGERT program, has allowed us to recruit strong students in this area, clearly describe the value of transdisciplinary approaches, and increase the reputation of UMassBoston for transdisciplinary problem solving, specifically in the area of coastal communities. Many of the outcomes of the IGERT Coasts and Communities program at UMassBoston have been institutionalized and can be seen in our current and future work.
